bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, November 15, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison gives Hench guidelines for Hench's article on his Camp Lazear discovery and the planned memorial.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, November 15, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
November 15, 1940

div1.p:
I am still carrying your letter back and
forth to the house wanting to write you personally,
and now comes this other one from you in New York
City. I find the surest way to write is to write
immediately and I want to add a few notes in answer
to this letter.

Thank you very much for the dope on the
shows. I have seen “Life with Father”, and your
reports on “George Washington” and “Louisiana Purchase”
confirm what I have heard. I do want to see Ed Wynn
in “Boys and Girls Together”.

In answer to your question about the article.
The purpose of this article is not to reproduce your
speech on Lazear. The purpose of it is to publicize
your discovery of the shack, the information about it,
and your plan for the building of a memorial in the
hopes that it will excite interest and perhaps
support. In dealing with newspapers, no one can tell
how much they would publish, but I should think that
six hundred words would be the outside limit and that
four hundred and fifty would be more likely to get in.
I think that it might be possible to get a couple of
cuts in our Red and Black and I am sure that we could.
Then we could have the reprint which you suggest with
both the article and the cut, and as many such reprints
as you would want. My suggestion would be to see what
you could do in a paper dispatch type of article written
in the third person about yourself and this cabin and
the memorial plan in about six hundred words, sending
the photographs which you would choose to have in with
it, say two of them, and we will try to get a nice setup
in the college paper reproduced also in the town paper,
and then as many reprints as possible. We will also
send it out to other papers and see if we can get it on
the associated press wire.

I have sent a memorandum to Mr. Brewer today
telling him that he is to send you five copies of each
of the photographs.

Your discoveries in the New York Public Library
are perfectly amazing. You ought to be in the research
business exclusively.

We all send our regards to you and I will be
writing more later. I am working hard now getting ready
for our semi-annual Board Meeting.
div1.closer:
Affectionately yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
RCH/M
